derivation.yuyuan_name: Middle English: from Old French, based on late Latin obsidatus 'the state of being a hostage' (the earliest sense in English), from Latin obses, obsid- 'hostage'

entry.def: A hostage is someone who has been captured by a person or organization and who may be killed or injured if people do not do what that person or organization demands.

example.ex: It is hopeful that two hostages will be freed in the next few days.
example.tran: 有两名人质可望在几天后获释。

entry.def: If someone is taken hostage or is held hostage, they are captured and kept as a hostage.

example.ex: He was taken hostage while on his first foreign assignment as a television journalist.
example.tran: 他第一次作为电视记者出国采访时就被扣作人质。

entry.tran: 受限制的人;不由自主的人
entry.def: If you say you are hostage to something, you mean that your freedom to take action is restricted by things that you cannot control.

example.ex: With the reduction in foreign investments, the government will be even more a hostage to the whims of the international oil price...
example.tran: 随着外资的减少，政府将更加受制于起伏不定的国际油价。

example.ex: Wine growers say they've been held hostage to the interests of the cereal and soybean farmers.
example.tran: 葡萄种植兼酿酒者说他们一直都为谷物和大豆种植者的利益所绑架。

means.word_mean: 1. a prisoner who is held by one party to insure that another party will meet specified terms
